jrobots.simulation.simulationObjects

Class PilotCommandProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • jrobots.simulation.simulationObjects.PilotCommandProcessor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class PilotCommandProcessor
extends java.lang.Thread
    Panzer.processPilotCommands is performed by an uninvolved thread, as to not execute external code in the same thread as the simulation. The simulation thread has the task to control this thread, as Pilot code may likely result in nontermination.

    Only use if you know what you're doing.

    Correct procedure is as follows:

    1. Call start().
    2. Wait using isAlive
    3. Call newJob() with job parameters.
    4. Call notify() on this thread.
    5. Call wait() on this thread, using some timeout value. If the caller is notified, the underlying Pilot terminated in time without exception.
    6. Repeat at 3. until program end or timeout.
    7. If there was a timeout, the Pilot probably hangs or has has thrown an exception. Construct a new command processor and restart at 1. A Pilot's exception is printed on System.err.
    8. At program end, you may want to interrupt this thread. It will end itself (this is untested).
